terms.definition: Measures the power distribution of a signal across different frequencies. Used to identify characteristic frequency patterns in drone communication signals.
In-phase and Quadrature components that represent complex RF signals, where I is the real part and Q is the imaginary part. Essential for capturing both amplitude and phase information.
Algorithm that converts time-domain signals into frequency-domain representation. Reveals the frequency components present in a signal.
Visual representation showing how signal frequencies change over time. Created by computing FFT on sliding windows of the signal.
DJI's proprietary communication protocol operating in 2.4GHz and 5.8GHz bands. One of the drone communication standards used in the dataset.
DJI's earlier communication protocol for drone control and video transmission. Features distinct RF characteristics for detection.
Classical ML algorithm that finds optimal hyperplanes to separate classes. Effective for RF signal classification with hand-crafted features.
Deep learning architecture that automatically learns spatial patterns. Applied to spectrograms for end-to-end drone signal classification.
Technique of using pre-trained model weights from one task as initialization for another. Reduces training time and data requirements.
When test data information inadvertently influences model training, leading to overly optimistic performance estimates. Critical issue to avoid in time-series RF data.
Algorithm for estimating power spectral density by averaging periodograms from overlapping signal segments. Reduces noise in frequency analysis.
Data partitioning approach that preserves class distribution proportions across train/validation/test sets. Essential for handling imbalanced drone datasets.
Public dataset containing RF signals from various drone models and communication protocols. Includes both drone and background interference signals.
Task of identifying signal types or sources from raw radio frequency measurements. Core objective of drone detection systems.
Frequency range occupied by a signal, typically measured in Hz or MHz. Different drone protocols use different bandwidths (e.g., 20MHz for WiFi).
Number of signal samples captured per second, measured in Hz. Determines the maximum frequency that can be accurately captured (Nyquist limit).
Specialized CNN architecture designed for RF-based drone detection. Uses multi-scale convolutional blocks optimized for spectrogram analysis.
Mathematical function applied to signal segments before FFT to reduce spectral leakage. Common types include Hamming, Hanning, and Blackman windows.
Table showing model predictions versus actual labels for each class. Reveals specific classification errors and class-wise performance.
Process of creating meaningful input variables from raw data for ML models. For RF signals, includes statistical, spectral, and temporal features.
Measure of similarity between a signal and a time-shifted version of itself. Used to find repeating patterns.
Signal centered around 0 Hz (DC) before modulation onto a carrier frequency.
Central frequency used to transport information in RF communications.
Unwanted constant component in a signal that shifts the baseline.
Technique where signal rapidly switches between frequency channels (e.g., Bluetooth uses 1600 hops/second).
Reference oscillator used for frequency conversion in RF receivers.
Maximum observable frequency, equal to half the sampling rate.
Property where two signals have zero correlation (dot product = 0).
Vector representation of a sinusoidal quantity showing amplitude and phase.
90-degree phase shift between two signals (the "Q" in IQ).
Radio system where signal processing is done in software rather than hardware.
Frequency spreading artifact caused by non-ideal windowing in FFT analysis.
